title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
First, let’s import the data!

library(readxl)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



wine_data <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx")

wine_data

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 7              62               0.32          0.16              7       0.045
 8               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 9              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>





Now that we have the data, let’s fix some of the non-standard names. To do this, we can use the second sheet of the dataset to get the names:

wine_data_columns <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx", sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx") [2])

wine_data_columns

# A tibble: 12 × 1
   Variables           
   <chr>               
 1 fixed_acidity       
 2 volatile_acidity    
 3 citric_acid         
 4 residual_sugar      
 5 chlorides           
 6 free_sulfur_dioxide 
 7 total_sulfur_dioxide
 8 density             
 9 pH                  
10 sulphates           
11 alcohol             
12 quality             


Now that we have the correct column names, we can rename the columns in our tibble. Since we have to rename all the columns and have a list of the corrected names, let’s use colnames.

colnames(wine_data) <- wine_data_columns[[1]]

wine_data

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>





For this task, we can use mutate to add a new column!

labeled_wine_data <- wine_data |>
  mutate(type = "white")

labeled_wine_data

# A tibble: 4,898 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>





Since this data is semi-colon delimited, we would use read_csv2, but since there are decimals in the numeric data, we will use read_delim.

wine_data2 <- read_delim("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/red-wine.csv", delim = ";")

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

wine_data2

# A tibble: 1,599 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 2             7.8               0.88          0                 2.6     0.098
 3             7.8               0.76          0.04              2.3     0.092
 4            11.2               0.28          0.56              1.9     0.075
 5             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 6             7.4               0.66          0                 1.8     0.075
 7             7.9               0.6           0.06              1.6     0.069
 8             7.3               0.65          0                 1.2     0.065
 9             7.8               0.58          0.02              2       0.073
10             7.5               0.5           0.36              6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


We can see that the column names include spaces, so let’s replace those with our column names from the other dataset.

colnames(wine_data2) <- wine_data_columns[[1]]

wine_data2

# A tibble: 1,599 × 12
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 2           7.8             0.88        0               2.6     0.098
 3           7.8             0.76        0.04            2.3     0.092
 4          11.2             0.28        0.56            1.9     0.075
 5           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 6           7.4             0.66        0               1.8     0.075
 7           7.9             0.6         0.06            1.6     0.069
 8           7.3             0.65        0               1.2     0.065
 9           7.8             0.58        0.02            2       0.073
10           7.5             0.5         0.36            6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Finally, we can add a new column for the color of the wine.

labeled_wine_data2 <- wine_data2 |>
  mutate(type = "red")

labeled_wine_data2

# A tibble: 1,599 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 2           7.8             0.88        0               2.6     0.098
 3           7.8             0.76        0.04            2.3     0.092
 4          11.2             0.28        0.56            1.9     0.075
 5           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 6           7.4             0.66        0               1.8     0.075
 7           7.9             0.6         0.06            1.6     0.069
 8           7.3             0.65        0               1.2     0.065
 9           7.8             0.58        0.02            2       0.073
10           7.5             0.5         0.36            6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>





Now, we can simply combine these two tibbles using bind_rows:

combined_wine_data <- bind_rows(labeled_wine_data, labeled_wine_data2)

combined_wine_data

# A tibble: 6,497 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 6,487 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>





Now, let’s start a chain that begins by filtering the data. Then we will sort the output of the filter by descending quality. Next, we use select to only keep columns that contain “acid”, alcohol, type, and quality.

altered_wine_data <- combined_wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5, alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(across(alcohol, list(mean = mean, sd = sd)))

altered_wine_data

# A tibble: 1,206 × 8
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality alcohol_mean
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>        <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9        122. 
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124 white       9        122. 
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125 white       9        122. 
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127 white       9        122. 
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129 white       9        122. 
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105 white       8         94.1
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
10            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: alcohol_sd <dbl>

title: Conceptual Questions
text:
To get a file located one directory above the current working directory, we can use the a relative path in combination with the command to move up a level. Therefore, the relative path would be “../MyData.csv”


The major benefits of using R projects include mostly saving certain attributes with a specifc task you are trying to achieve in R. Therefore, if you create an R project for a specific homework assignment, things like the working directory, workspace, history, and folder structure and source documents are all saved into that project making it easier to open and pick up where you left off or collaborate.


Git is a version control software that allows data scientists and other programmers to easy track changes and collaborate on projects that they are working on. Github is an online hosting service for Git projects, allowing users to have remote repos that are tracked by Git.


The two main differences between a tibble and data.frame are: the printing of a tibble is cleaner and easier to read in its default form compared to a data.frame and tibbles do not coerce down to a vector when you subset to a single column.


If we wanted to utilize the BaseR chaining operator “|>” to give this function more readibility, we could write: “iris |> as_tibble() |> select(, starts_with(”Petal”), Species) |> filter(, Petal.Length < 1.55) |> arrange(, Species)”

title: Homework 4
text: Thanks Dr. Post for putting together this easy to use template!

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
First, we will need to read in the data. Looking at the data available at the URL, it appears to be comma delimited. Therefore, we can simply use read_csv.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



data_tbl <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/glass.data", col_names = c("Id", "RI", "Na", "Mg", "Al", "Si", "K", "Ca", "Ba", "Fe", "TypeGlass"))

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, TypeGlass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

data_tbl

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe TypeGlass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0            1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0            1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0            1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0            1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0            1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26         1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0            1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0            1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0            1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11         1
# ℹ 204 more rows





Now, we can chain together a mutate function and filter to rename the values of the last column and filter to the desired data:

filtered_mapped_data <- data_tbl |> 
  mutate(TypeGlass = 
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 1, "building_windows_float_processed", 
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 2, "building_windows_non_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 3, "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 4, "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 5, "containers",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 6, "tableware", "headlamps"))))))) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2, (TypeGlass %in% c("tableware", "headlamps")))
  
filtered_mapped_data

# A tibble: 38 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe TypeGlass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    
 1   177  1.52  14    2.39  1.56  72.4  0     9.57  0        0 tableware
 2   178  1.52  13.8  2.41  1.19  72.8  0     9.77  0        0 tableware
 3   179  1.52  14.5  2.24  1.62  72.4  0     9.26  0        0 tableware
 4   180  1.52  14.1  2.19  1.66  72.7  0     9.32  0        0 tableware
 5   181  1.51  14.4  1.74  1.54  74.6  0     7.59  0        0 tableware
 6   182  1.52  15.0  0.78  1.74  72.5  0     9.95  0        0 tableware
 7   183  1.52  14.2  0     2.09  72.7  0    10.9   0        0 tableware
 8   184  1.52  14.6  0     0.56  73.5  0    11.2   0        0 tableware
 9   185  1.51  17.4  0     0.34  75.4  0     6.65  0        0 tableware
10   186  1.51  13.7  3.2   1.81  72.8  1.76  5.43  1.19     0 headlamps
# ℹ 28 more rows

title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
First, let’s import the data!

library(readxl)
library(tidyverse)

title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Now that we have the data, let’s fix some of the non-standard names. To do this, we can use the second sheet of the dataset to get the names:

wine_data_columns <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx", sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx") [2])

wine_data_columns

10 sulphates           
11 alcohol             
12 quality             


Now that we have the correct column names, we can rename the columns in our tibble. Since we have to rename all the columns and have a list of the corrected names, let’s use colnames.

colnames(wine_data) <- wine_data_columns[[1]]

We can see that the column names include spaces, so let’s replace those with our column names from the other dataset.

colnames(wine_data2) <- wine_data_columns[[1]]

wine_data2

# A tibble: 1,599 × 12
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides

Finally, we can add a new column for the color of the wine.

labeled_wine_data2 <- wine_data2 |>
  mutate(type = "red")

#   type <chr>

title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Now, we can simply combine these two tibbles using bind_rows:

combined_wine_data <- bind_rows(labeled_wine_data, labeled_wine_data2)

combined_wine_data

# A tibble: 6,497 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05

 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 6,487 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>

title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Now, let’s start a chain that begins by filtering the data. Then we will sort the output of the filter by descending quality. Next, we use select to only keep columns that contain “acid”, alcohol, type, and quality.

altered_wine_data <- combined_wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5, alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(across(alcohol, list(mean = mean, sd = sd)))

altered_wine_data

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
First, we will need to read in the data. Looking at the data available at the URL, it appears to be comma delimited. Therefore, we can simply use read_csv.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



data_tbl <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/glass.data", col_names = c("Id", "RI", "Na", "Mg", "Al", "Si", "K", "Ca", "Ba", "Fe", "TypeGlass"))

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Now, we can chain together a mutate function and filter to rename the values of the last column and filter to the desired data:

filtered_mapped_data <- data_tbl |> 
  mutate(TypeGlass = 
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 1, "building_windows_float_processed", 
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 2, "building_windows_non_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 3, "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 4, "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 5, "containers",
    ifelse(TypeGlass == 6, "tableware", "headlamps"))))))) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2, (TypeGlass %in% c("tableware", "headlamps")))
  
filtered_mapped_data

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Problem 1
First we read in the data. Here it appears to be fixed field data, so we will use read_table:

yeast_data_tbl <- read_table("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/yeast.data", col_names = c("seq_name", "mcg", "gvh", "alm", "mit", "erl", "pox", "vac", "nuc", "class"))


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
cols(
  seq_name = col_character(),
  mcg = col_double(),
  gvh = col_double(),
  alm = col_double(),
  mit = col_double(),
  erl = col_double(),
  pox = col_double(),
  vac = col_double(),
  nuc = col_double(),
  class = col_character()
)

yeast_data_tbl

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Problems 2 and 3
For the first part, we can simply select all columns except seq_name and nuc. Next, we can chain that output into a group_by and a mutate across those groups to add in the mean and median for each numeric field.

yeast_data_group <- yeast_data_tbl |>
  select(-seq_name, -nuc) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, median = median)))

yeast_data_group
